Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Simultaneous Modeling and Calibration for Environmental Sensor Data

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ECCS-1342121
Balzano, Laura
University of Michigan
BRIGE: Simultaneous Modeling and Calibration for Environmental Sensor Data

ABSTRACT

Intellectual Merit: This BRIGE project is aimed at the investigation of signal processing theory and methods for blindly calibrating sensors on a massive scale, after they are deployed, and as their calibrations change over time. The massive deployment of sensors is exciting for the prospect of what may be learned from the data; a critical challenge in using those data is knowing their quality and reliability. In deployments of even a hundred sensors, it becomes infeasible to hand-calibrate each one in order to maintain confidence in the sensor output. Thus blind calibration, i.e. calibration without the need for controlled stimulus or high fidelity ground-truth data, is of critical importance. This proposal focuses both on theory of blind calibration and the concrete practical application to air quality sensing. Realistic sensing environments are considered, where phenomena are non-stationary, and data are streaming, with corruptions and missing values. A calibration dataset will be collected and shared with the community. The two major theoretical contributions will be (1) extending theory of blind calibration to models which capture the great variety exhibited by environmental phenomena, and (2) online modeling for the practical scenario where the phenomenon of interest is non-stationary.

Broader Impacts: Environmental sensing is an important contemporary application of statistical signal processing that attracts a great deal of interest from people with diverse backgrounds. This application gets people involved in the technology, the climate, and their local community; therefore it has potential to truly broaden participation in engineering. The syllabus for Digital Signal Processing at the University of Michigan, a central course in all signal processing curricula, will be expanded to include this application and useful fundamentals like spatial models, auto-regressive models, and matrix decomposition. Additionally, signal processing for environmental sensing in particular has the potential to attract students who may typically go into science or environmental policy, but who have a strong interest in mathematics as well. Interaction with the Marian Sarah Parker Scholars program at Michigan will expose outstanding young female scientists to the wide variety of possibilities with signal processing. Beyond the classroom, exploring one's environment using sensing has the potential to make a very positive social impact. The projects developed for the Parker scholars and other Michigan educational programs will build an infrastructure for future interactions with all grade levels and the greater public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this information age, we have the opportunity to collect sensor data to help us understand more about our health and environment. The massive deployment of environmental sensors is exciting for the prospect of what may be learned about how our environment impacts our health and welfare. However, these deployments have been slow to grow, and one critical challenge hindering environmental data collection is knowing their quality and reliability. In deployments of even a hundred sensors, it becomes infeasible to hand-calibrate each one in order to maintain confidence in the sensor output. Thus blind calibration, i.e. calibration without the need for controlled stimulus or high fidelity ground-truth data, is of critical importance. This proposal focused both on theory of blind calibration and the concrete practical application to air quality sensing. We wanted to consider realistic sensing environments, where phenomena are non-stationary and data are streaming, with corruptions and missing values.

 

The intellectual merit of our project was focused on both data collection and methodology to address this sensor calibration issue. We started by collecting a calibration dataset of ozone measurements from the AirNow environmental monitoring network. In the figures you can see a plot of the ozone measurements in the state of Pennsylvania; the black dots are the sensor locations, and we have interpolated the measurements using kriging.

 

Then we made two algorithmic contributions for the implementation of blind calibration. The first is an algorithm for solving for calibration coefficients with the assumption that the true signal can be modeled by a particular model class called the “subspace model.” Building on prior work, we made this algorithm robust to incorrect specification of the subspace model, and studied at what point this algorithm breaks down. Diagrams showing the calibration error as a function of known sensor gains (calibrated sensors in the dataset) and subspace model error can be seen for the previous state of the art “Least Squares LS,” and our improvement “Total Least Squares TLS.”

 

Our second contribution is an algorithm for learning that subspace model from historical environmental data. We wanted to learn a subspace model with sparse spatial structure, so that we can see the environmental phenomena occurring across space in the signal. We also wanted the algorithm to handle missing data, because these sensors aren’t always reliable or synchronized, and to be online in the sense that it processes one data point at a time. In this way the algorithm can learn a subspace model from data and then use it for calibration of the sensors.

 

The broader impacts of our project are both in environmental sensing and public health as well as in signal processing education. While our focus was on air pollution sensing, the ideas and algorithms are applicable to any environmental sensing application: from water, to soil, to other ambient properties like rain, wind, pressure, and temperature. As we make blind calibration more practical for real sensor systems, it will enable real scientific conclusions based on citizen-collected data. Environmental sensing is an important contemporary application of statistical signal processing that attracts a great deal of interest from students with diverse backgrounds. This application gets people involved in the technology, the climate, and their local community; therefore it has potential to truly broaden participation in engineering. As a part of this project we expanded the syllabus for Digital Signal Processing (DSP) at Michigan, a central course in all signal processing curricula, to include this application and useful fundamentals like spatial models, auto-regressive models, and matrix decomposition. We added a project component to DSP that allows students to collect and analyze their own data; the students love being involved and many are inspired by the environmental applications.

 

Our work was presented at the American Geophysical Union conference, the Allerton conference on communication, control, and computing, and the International conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing.
